intro: Pseudocrupina arabica, commonly known as the Arabian false cumin, is a flowering plant native to the Arabian Peninsula. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils. Pseudocrupina arabica is valued for its aromatic seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a spice in some cuisines.
